content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: looks nice and easy to solve in 5 minutes

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: like the idea :smile:
Nice contribution. You could have a test case with n > 26 ;)

Good reverse puzzle, and good formatting.

However, your validators don't match their associated tests. For example, your first example has a space inside, but its validator is just a single world. Another example: Test 7 has a non-alphanumeric symbol in it, but its validator doesn't. 
As a reminder, validators are not meant to add more test cases (they're hidden after all), but mainly to prevent hardcoding.
(By the way, Validator 7 is named "This should give it away", but since validators are hidden in actual play, players will never see this.)

Another thing, I don't think N is necessary for this puzzle; maybe there are languages that would require it to parse a string, but I can't think of any on the top of my head; if I'm wrong, please correct me.

That said, I like this, fun to code a solution for it too.
Please delete one of these contributions please :)

Hello Linkyu
Thanks for the feedback. To be honest i didn't really understand the difference between a test and a validator. I just saw them as different test cases. 

I could switch validator 1 (ie test 2)  with test 3 and throw in a non-alpha into the validator. 

As far for the n necessary or not I agree but just because I couldn't think of a language that needs it doesn't mean it doesn't exist so I threw it in there for safety. 

Thanks

My solution in JS (works with n>26) :

readline()
a='ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ'
print([...readline()].map((x,i)=>a.includes(x)?a[(a.indexOf(x)-i+26)%26]:x).join('')

Any length could work cause it is cyclic but I didn't want to make it too confusing given that it is reverse...
Thanks for the feedback though

When you are clashing and you "play testcases", the Tests are what you are playing. i.e. coders get to see the inputs and outputs of the Tests.

When you submit your solution and the system evaluates it and gives you a score, it is the Validations that it plays. i.e. coders never get to see those inputs or outputs.

A test / validation pair should be similar but not identical, so that the coder cannot hardcode a submission (for validation) based on the test result. 

e.g. if your function was to add 1 to a number, you might code input: 1 and output: 2 as a test, and input: 6 and output: 7 as the associated validation. If the coder can't work out the method, they might hardcode 'if input = 1, output = 2' to pass the test, but that would fail the validation, and they couldn't hardcode anything to pass the validation because they never see it.
